commit.message: Add a few more ordinary meeting types to graffiti
Move religious meetings to their own section.
Add Gozag to religious graffiti.
Add another graffiti religion line.
Add another graffiti argument line.

Move species-based graffiti into its own section.

Also, add a second entry to it so that it doesn't have only one.
Move a few more graffiti msgs into short sayings.
Reorder a graffiti section.
@graffiti_meeting_type@ -> @graffiti meeting@
Move graffiti rumours into their own section.

Move religious graffiti into its own section(s).

Beogh gets a separate section from the rest because Beogh's graffiti
needs orc authors. Also, add a second Beogh entry to it so that it
doesn't have only one.
Add graffiti unique complaints, tweak & sign them
Move short graffiti sayings into their own section.
Add a graffiti line about coglins.

Add and adjust more religious graffiti.

Yredelemnul and Zin now have lines.

Tweak new mutation icons and description

This adds new tiles for Meek and Spatial Entanglement, and fixes another
typo in the description for the latter.

Tile credits:
 * Meek: CanofWorm's Weapon Gift invocation icon
 * Spatial Entanglement: Roctavian's Portal Projectile icon, a CC0 ribbon
   by Shade, and a CC0 gun by SnoopethDuckDuck.

Nerf protean grace

With the removal of berserkitis in 143df15, the dual reworks of inability
to drink and read terminating in 1ae03d7 and c8003b0, and the nerf of
teleportitis in 18b0d3c, the ceiling of bad mutations has been lowered a
fair bit. When combined with the reduced permanent malmutation across the
game under the current strategic damage schema, as well as more good
mutations just this version like Lucky (e722901), the expected value of
potions of mutation has risen by a lot. I had added the Protean Grace
mutation in a229ff6 as a valuable high-roll before such bad mutation
reworks, but the numbers in practice can easily go quite high, and both
mutation gods are far from weak at the moment, so I'd prefer to nudge this
mutation back down.

Previously, the mutation had a soft cap of 7, where it'd halve the
scaling of mutations to Slaying and EV to every other mutation. Now, it
applies this halving at all times, and also rounds up by default: just
having one or two mutations provides +1/+1, three or four provides +2/+2,
and so on upwards. This should both be a little less kludgy with the
absence of an exact cap, and still get some benefit from having good
and bad mutations alike, but still avoiding the extremely high benefits
for temporary whiles under Xom and Jiyva. It's a bit of a shame of a
nerf, but potion of mutation gambling has become quite rewarding
currently, and it's better than cutting out more possibilities entirely.

Fix webbed players sometimes getted netted instead (TheMagicFish)

Since we were applying 'damage' to your ATTR_HELD from stuggling against it
*before* removing the held status, if the damage done to the net exactly
erased its remaining HP, you would appear not to be held by anything at all
by the time stop_being_caught() was checking if you were in a net. And
since you were not in a net, it would not clean up the prop that indicated
you were in a net, causing the next time you were webbed actually net you
instead.

It was even possible to obtain a net this way by blinking out again!

Fix explore teleport traps being silent and non-hostile (tswn)

They were printing no message whatsoever when triggering (at least if you
weren't with Ash), and then not even bothering to teleport you to monsters.

Whoops.
Fix Lucky having a 1% trigger chance for everyone (tswn)
Allow graffiti to use colour patterns.

Restore a sparkling fountain decor message.

Now that coloured graffiti (and its subset of coloured text) are
separate from coloured patterns, and all patterns are consistently
plural, make it pulsate any colour pattern again.

Tweak it slightly to account for the plural.
Fix description of stat-loss mutations (Undo)

Unbreak windows builds

As near as I can tell, S_NORMAL (used for some monster shouts) conflicts
with... *something* SDL/OpenGL-related and 03cf731 very incidentally
resulted in an include path where glwrapper-ogl.cc now transitively
includes mon-enum.h, which tries to redefine this and fails.

It looked like this problem may have been run into before, and 'fixed' by
7376cb9 undefining S_NORMAL, but I have opted to just rename the enum
instead. (It's barely used anyway.)
Fix header-build-tests
Fix typo.

Fix a possible exploit with Spatial Entanglement

If there was only a single monster in sight (or the player got lucky),
attacking a monster with Vhi's could cause it to blink *away* from you,
setting up another Vhi's while leaving the monster stunned from the blink
it just dead. In theory, this could allow you to Vhi's the same monster
until it died.

(Instead, just don't move monsters that are already eligable to your
destination.)

Disable the contamination susceptible mutation for now

While there were theoretical future plans to use contam costs more widely,
at the moment this badmut is very narrow in its application: it makes one
specific spell much worse to use, exactly 3 enemies worse to fight, and not
much else. (Doubling contam from miscasts will almost never matter since
reaching 50% contam via miscasts alone is incredibly unlikely with the
current system.).

I am leaving the code in for now, since I can see a mildly reworked version
of it being relevant in future. But for now, let's not have it taking
weight away from more relevant/interesting mutations.

Greatly buff mutagenic gaze contam

While reworking shining eyes was intended to reduce the feelsbad spikiness
of them immediately malmutating you upon being first seen, the buildup was
too gentle in practice. The goal wasn't to *remove* malmutate as a
relevant mechanic in Slime, and that seems like a common reaction to the
result. So let's ramp it up a bunch.

(Concerns have been expressed that, regardless of intensity, this makes
stairdancing significantly more attractive in Slime than before. That is
a larger problem, with some proposed solutions that may be tried at a
later date.)
Fix door opening always interrupting travel (Lici)

Fix talisman transformations getting an interrupt prompt as you finished

It didn't actually matter whether you told the prompt to continue or not,
since it was already completed by this point (but the delay wasn't cleared
yet).

(This was apparently quietly suppressed by the delay being uninterruptable
from its second-last turn, which was changed by 66e16baa.)
Fix removing all contam sometimes not clearing the UI indicator properly

Adjust flooded duration stacking

While the flooded status was a potentially-scary but manageable debuff in
most encounters, the fact that additional hits could maintain an existing
debuff meant that in the worst case (such as multiple void oozes in melee
at once), the player might never regain their ability to speak or read
scrolls. And while !lig is potential counterplay in some situations, it
probably cannot count in ones that late into the game. Dying this way feels
bad, so let's prevent the player from being re-flooded until 1 turn after
the last time wore off.

Make Weak/Dopey/Clumsy mutations give an additional -1 stat per level

These were a pretty weak effect, and alongside removing/taming some of the
most terrible badmuts in this version, we want to raise the floor a little.

Since stat 0 is no longer such an abrupt awfulness, I think we can afford
to be a tiny bit more aggressive here. (Tempmuts don't give out stat
maluses anymore, so it's impossible to lose -6 in one cast.)

Make Lucky mutation trigger slightly more often

Response to this mutation was positive, though the odds of it producing
even one item the player cares about still seems low, so let's raise it
slightly.

New bad mutation: Meek

A very simple one that just gives -3/5/7 slaying, rounding out the variety
of 'modest, inobtrusive penalty' and filling a tiny bit of the 'anti-melee'
space that berserkitis once occupied.

Fix a few issues with listing of monster gear

Monsters who were carrying unbranded throwing weapons (commonly large
rocks, but also javelins or boomerangs) would be announced with 'You
encounter an X. It is  .' Fix this (and also consider non-large rock
missiles notable enough to be announced on encounter, even if they were
unbranded - until now, plain boomerangs and javelins were never announced!)

Also, the full gear description when hovering the cursor over a monster was
accidentally hiding 'uninteresting' items since b9f8b6a76. Fix this.

New bad mutation: Spatial Entanglement

This mutation gives a 66% chance, whenever you move via a translocation,
of pulling a single random monster along for the ride. If you move to
somewhere in LoS of your old position, it pulls a random monster previously
in LoS of you (preferring monsters not still in LoS of your new location).
If you move teleport further away, it can pull a random monster from
anywhere else on the floor.

The monster pulled is stunned for one turn, ensuring the player can always
act again before they can.

Slightly rework Screaming mutation

A chance to cause a shout to happen upon first spotting a monster was not
actually very different from how encountering monsters normally works;
there is almost always a chance rolled when you first encounter a monster
for a shout to happen: the monster's. And, in fact, even when the player
possesses considerable stealth, that chance is still much higher each turn
than the chance of you screaming at them, despite the latter only being
able to happen on a single turn. (In pratice, even with overwhelming
stealth, this mutation is almost always less bad than remaining even one
single extra turn in a monster's LoS).

Instead, try differentiating it a little more from regular stealth checks
by making it a chance to scream upon taking damage instead. (This is
currently a 5/10% chance on sustaining damage, and the volume of the
shouting is also increased slightly.)

Make attractitis a regular bad mutation

After hanging around in the codebase since the initial steel elves version,
attractitis is finally enabled as a regular bad mutation, with a couple
small tweaks:
 -It is now a 2-level mutation, with level 2 doubling the activation
  chance.
 -It now has a 50% chance of waking up any monsters pulled by it (though
  not alerting themselves to the player's position, so stealthy characters
  may still remain briefly unnoticed).

-----------------------------

Mutation icon made by regret-index, combining PleasingFungus's Lesser
Beckoning tile with NormalPerson7's Malmutate icon.

Fix a tiny number of issues caught by static analysis

Mostly some low-hanging fruit.

Move many functions out of view.cc

In theory, view.cc was supposed to be about rendering the dungeon, but had
accumulated an incresing number of functions over time about handling
'things in view of the player', like stealth checks and monster encounter
messages. Also, seen_monster() was in mon-poly.cc for some reason.

Move most of these into a new player-notices.cc, with a few other functions
going to mon-act.cc or map-knowledge.cc as felt vaguely appropriate.

(This also makes a single minor change of removing a superfluous argument
from seen_monsters_react())

Tweak an assert

For reasons that are somewhat unclear to me, relocating the ME_EVAL check
to _place_monster_aux in c24fba173 resulted in this assert tripping in
arena since their target remained unset (and the player doesn't exist, so
is always at (0, 0) at this point).

However, I don't think that's tripping the *spirit* of the assert, since
they're not actually targeting the player - they're just targeting nothing
- so just adjusting the assert seems plausibly correct to me.

New UI option: monster_alert

Any monster specified by this option will cause a --More-- upon being first
encountered by the player. This is intended as a more reliable replacement
to the force_more_messages commonly used by many players to catch 'comes
into view' messages for certain monsters.

It will trigger even in cases where a standard encounter message is not
printed (such as when a monster is summoned) and includes some special
values to make it more convenient to alert on a range of monsters:
 -'uniques' will alert on any unique
 -'nasty', 'tough', 'easy', 'trivial' will alert on any monster whose
  threat level is at least that high. (I personally think 'nasty' is the
  only potentially useful one of these, but I know some other people will
  disagree, and implementing the rest was basically free.)
 -'unusual' will alert on any monster carrying 'unusual' items, as
  specified by unusual_monster_items

Of these, only 'uniques' is enabled by default. While there are others that
are arguably useful, this is the only one that feels of objective value in
a way that would make sense to newcomers as well (finding a unique is
almost always at least a noteworthy event).

Remove some non-functional flush_reason_types and options

Most of these were undocumented and (as far as I can tell) never
functional. FLUSH_ON_MESSAGE *once* did something (but stopped
approximately 16 years ago). However, it doesn't feel like it would be
terribly useful even if it did work (flushing macro input on it producing
any messages at all seems countproductive) so I'm simply removing it.

Also minimally document the one flush_reason_type that actually does
something via an option.

Flush the input buffer on printing a forced --more--

force_more_message is intended to interrupt the player upon potentially
critical events happening, but if somehow multiple keypresses were still
in the input buffer at the time, it would merely 'pause' playback of them,
and resume taking actions 'automatically' once the --more-- was cleared.
It was very realistic for this to result in the player skipping through
several turns *after* the force_more was printed (even multiple
force_mores), especially if slow animations like screen flashes were
happening at the time.

Since the entire point of these --mores-- is to interrupt the player (and
often act as a sort of 'safety net' when certain events happen), they
should actually interrupt. Thus we now flush the input buffer whenever a
forced more occurrs, just in case (though not for any --mores-- caused by
show_more_message)

(I wasn't able to reproduce this bug on Windows, very plausibly due to
different keyboard input handling - but it happens in both local tiles on
Linux and webtiles, and probably elsewhere; I think it's probably quite
old.)

Don't merge same-genus monsters in condensed monster descriptions

If the player encountered enough different types of monsters at once (some
of which shared the same genus), the game would unhelpfully condensed the
message to the form of "You encounter 27 humans." Which humans? Is a vault
warden one of them? It's impossible to tell!

This is important information, and I feel like very little is gained by
compressing it together.

I've retained genus compression for now only for derived undead, who
typically occur in groups of more types at once, while having fewer
significant differences between those types. Though I could be convinced
that it isn't helpful here, either.

Allow listing only armour in condensed monster equipment descriptions

Instead of being obligated to point out that the orc wizard is wielding a
+0 dagger just because they're wearing a +2 robe of fire resistance.

Also clean up some enum names and remove some code for handling
descriptions of monsters with unidentified gear.
Fix some item name functions not fully respecting the 'identified' argument

Add 'dancing' to the name of dancing weapons

I was actually surprised to realize nothing in-game actually calls them
dancing weapons at all, considering everyone else does.

It strikes me as slightly odd that the message for encountering a long
sword on the floor and a long sword that wants to kill you are so similar,
so let's make them a little more different.

Refactor to fix many issues with see_monster interrupts and messages

The "Comes into view" messages printed when monsters were first encountered
(along with equipment warnings) were deeply entangled with activity
interrupts in a way that lead to multiple problems:
 -Situations where the player could not be interrupted would sometimes
  suppress all such messages (eg: monsters first encountered upon entering
  new floor would print no equipment warnings since stair travel is
  uncancellable).
 -Situations that *might* be the first time a monster came into view
  required special handling to avoid printing duplicate messages, which
  itself was prone to bugs. For instance, if a monster the player had
  not yet seen opened a door while the player was not in the middle of
  delay, no message would be printed about the door opening at all.
 -Even in cases where the above worked, messaging was not always consistent
  between 'monster did a thing' and 'monster you hadn't before seen did
  that same thing' due to the latter occurring in a very different function
  which lacked full context of the 'usual' message.
 -Certain special messages for encountering monsters (such as monsters in
  the Abyss appearing in sight of the player) would often not be used
  unless the player was performing a delay at the time.

There was also a great deal of duplicated code to handle printing these
'comes into view' messages depending on their timing (which also resulted
in duplicated code for handling Shoutitis, Gozag Incite, and Attractitis),
along with message-handling for many long-removed things like monsters
unsubmerging, being freshly spawned from adjacent floors via stairs, or
even unbreathing monsters walking out of deep water again.

To top this off, due to relying on see_monster interrupts to notice
eligible monsters, Shoutitis (including maw form), Gozag Incite (and
Attractitis, were it enabled) could be turned off by user option - monsters
included in runrest_ignore_monster will never produce interrupts or comes
into view messages, thus never triggering these effects! Madness.

Beyond this, see_monster interrupts themselves functioned in ways that
often caught players by surprise. Because they could only be fired for
monsters the player has *never* seen before, a common scenario involved
fleeing from a dangerous monster, much later starting to change armour with
no monster in sight, and then having that same monster walk back into
sight, spend several turns approaching the player with no notification
until they clobbered them in the head. When this happened with something
like an early ogre, it could be directly fatal.

This commit makes many structural changes to improve this situation:
 -see_monster interrupts can now be fired for previously-encountered
  monsters, so long as they were not in sight when a delay was started.
 -Messaging for normal monster actions no longer depends on interrupt
  messages in any scenario, untangling "monster did a thing" and "you first
  noticed a monster" entirely.
  -In cases where a previously-encountered monster triggers an interrupt,
   a shorter message will be displayed so that the player knows what caused
   it.
 -"X comes into view." is replaced with "You encounter X.", which removes
  much of the need to control message ordering so strictly to ensure it is
  printed first in all scenarios (which was a regular source of bugs), as
  well as potentially being more intuitive to newcomers (after all,
  monsters come into view all the time without getting that message!)
 -Encountering a single monster and encountering multiple monsters at once
  now share the same encounter message code.
 -Shoutitis, attractitis, and Gozag wrath no longer depend on interrupts,
  but merely encountering a new monster.
 -Many unused messages are removed (and a few have their wording improved).
 -Command repetition no longer ignores the presence of monsters if they
  came into view on the first turn of repetition.
 -Abyss monsters now consistently produce special messages when created in
  sight of the player (and their band members now also do so, as well as
  properly producing translocation clouds).
  -Using the same technique, monsters spawned in sight of the player on the
   orb run now say something more than just 'X comes into view'.
 -Monsters previously sensed by monster detection can now interrupt travel
  again if the player actually leaves the floor (it was harder to think of
  a better metric for this).
 -Probably a handful of more minor things I have forgotten.

Fix band members not fully inheriting their designated foe upon creation

For monsters created mid-game as part of bands (often via Shadow Creatures
or orb run spawns), only the band leader would be properly seeking their
designated foe.

This *often* didn't cause many issues in practice, since even having this
information set partially would usually cause the monster to still pick an
appropriate foe immediately afterward, but they did spawn with question
marks over their head and if you broke LoS from orbrun spawns immediately,
they would often be left wandering (unlike their leader).

Remove a seemingly unnecessary conditional

The comment probably refers to old butchery autoswap, which was long gone
even before food itself was (which is also long-gone).

I can't think of any way that observing monsters should cause you to take
an action that ends your turn (and in fact it might be dangerous if it did,
given how many other places this can be called).

Don't anger good neutrals with Cause Fear, Anguish, or Word of Chaos

In general, I feel like any AoE that already don't have friendly fire
should also ignore good neutrals (and many of them do, since wont_attack()
and mons_aligned() include both friendly and good-neutral and are used in
many similar effects).

The very few places this makes ?fear more useful than before (largely
involving Bribe Branch) don't seem worth preserving this minor difference
between ally-safe and extremely-ally-safe effects.

Fix player translocations not interrupting delays as intended

And remove activity_interrupt::teleport since it's effectively baked into
MV_TRANSLOCATIONS now.

Slightly improve message for monsters blinking out of constriction

Don't claim that jumping spiders 'blinked' out of anything, and condense
the escape message and regular message together instead of printing a
similar thing twice.

Rename armour_off/armour_on delays and update options_guide.txt

These are now equip_on and equip_off (they've included jewellery and
Coglin weapons since 0.33).

Also remove a few old default activity interrupts (like interrupt_butcher)
and upgrade options_guide.txt to remove references to several other removed
delays.

(Also fix Imprint Weapon not getting properly interrupted.)

Remove activity_interrupt::stat_change

Stat loss is no longer a significant enough event to prompt the player to
cancel delays, even if it somehow happened in the middle of them doing
something.

Flush messages before prompting the player to cancel delays

If the player was prompted to stop a delay because (for instance) they
just got hit by something, the message for getting hit would not
necessarily be printed in the message log yet, making it sometimes quite
mysterious *why* you were being asked this question.

Don't make many delays uninterruptible on their second-last turn

If something tried to interrupt taking on/off equipment, transforming, or
imbuing a spellspark servitor on the second-last turn, nothing would
happen, happily allowing the player to sometimes get hit in the face by
something which would be otherwise avoidable. (One of the more common
scenarios involves Xom summons or god wrath.)

Looking through git history, this (duration > 1) check was originally put
in with the reasoning that choosing to cancel on the final turn still
consumed time for no benefit anyway. However, this does not seem to be the
case in modern Crawl and does allow the player to cancel a turn earlier
than they othewise would (possibly this changed the last time delays were
significantly refactored ~9 years ago?)
Add an autogenerated file to gitignore

New bad mutation: Spiteful Blood

This mutation gives a chance that the player's own blood rises up to fight
them when enough of it is spilled. When falling below 50% max HP, an
erythrospite may spawn adjacent to you - an angry mass of spilled blood
with HP and attack damage that scales with a factor of the player's XL
(and vampiric attacks, but poor defenses).

If one spawns, a second will not be able to spawn until the player heals
fully (and then gets significant reinjured).

At the second level of this mutation, two erythrospites may spawn at the
same time.

Damage, spawn chance, and other details are provisional, but this is a
further attempt at trying new angles for more interesting badmuts (that are
also not intended to be backbreaking).

Mutation tiles for Renounce Potions/Scrolls (regret-index)

Tiles were made by regret-index, using ontoclasm's Sacrifice Hand, Words,
and Drink ability icons

Reduce potion/scroll hoarding to one level, and restrict to Ru sacs

While these mutations may have lacked the dissatisfying RNG of the previous
-potion/scroll mutations, reaction to them in practice was mixed, with many
people finding them *more* oppressive than the old ones to recieve as
random malmuts and generally a bit unfun. There was particular concern with
this regarding Xom, where a player might end up restricted in this way for
quite a while.

However, players still seemed to consider them better-designed than the
previous mutations in this role as a Ru sacrifice, so I have restricted
them to this role, reducing them from 2 levels to 1 (and setting the
restriction of each at 50% HP). It's still a little unclear to me if their
piety gain should be adjusted - even experienced players seemed divided on
the subject.

(I have also reflavoured them a little to fit Ru's theme better, now that
they are Ru-exclusive again.)

A simple icon for showing Strong-Willed on monsters

It was previously merely implied by spriggan berserkers gaining
regeneration, but the flight status given by !enlightenment also has no
icon, and this felt like the better of the two to give.

New bad/good mutation: Potion Fungus

This mutation causes a fungus to grow on the player's body which sometimes
shares the effect of beneficial potions they drink with other monsters.
ie: drinking !haste can haste things, !hw can heal things, and so forth.

This *can* affect allies, but since there are a lot more enemies in the
game than allies (and many characters have no allies at all), this is
intended to be primarily a negative mutation (that can sometimes be
manipulated to be positive). (I admit, I was motivated by it feeling more
incoherant on a flavor level if it specifically only affected enemies....)

Double-sided potions are not included - partially because they're more
complex to imagine for monsters, and also far easier for the player to
exploit for actual benefit.

Intended to vaguely fill potion hording's slot in the general mutation
pool.

(Mutation tile made by regret-index, using ontoclasm's potion tile and old
glowing mold tiles, Sastreii's robust tile, and a CC0 mushroom by Jetrel.)

New bad mutation: Booming Voice

Intended to replace Scroll Hording from the general mutation pool, this
causes the player to produce Gong-level noise when they read scrolls in
view of enemies.

Hopefully this lateral approach to an anti-scroll mutation will feel less
repressive while still having a meaningful impact on how and when the
player uses scrolls.

(Mutation tile made by regret-index, using ontoclasm's alarm trap tile, and
a CC0 scroll by idyllwilds.)

Rework teleportitis somewhat (regret-index)

Several times in past, the idea was floated to make the teleportitis
mutation work closer to sojourning bolt (ie: warning the player in advance,
and allowing them to spend teleport scrolls to avoid it when crucial). The
hope was that this might feel a little less backbreaking and a bit more
agentive on players parts.

The way teleportitis (and hostile teleport in general) previously worked is
that it would repeatedly attempt a fully random teleport, and then reroll
the destination if there weren't monsters in sight. This usually failed
silently, but at a rate that had a complex relationship with how many
monsters were on a floor and how open it was. For instance, the chance of
teleportitis succeeding when called on an uncleared early D floor was ~30%,
potentially dipping to ~10% when the floor was nearly empty (but could be
as high as ~80% on V:5!).

Getting teleported to monsters is *already* more dangerous in places full
of monsters (like V:5), even if it happened at the same rate there as
elsewhere, rather than several times higher.

The new method (using code from wyrmholes) is guaranteed to teleport the
player into sight of *some* monster, if there are any. I have set the
trigger rate vaguely approximating the 'average' prior chance, plus a
little bit more to account for being able to cancel the scariest teleports
in advance. (I have also given it an internal cooldown to avoid feelsbad
situations with using ?tele only to immediately start teleporting anyway).

A few other things relied on the same 'usually fails' hostile teleport
code: Lugonu wrath, distortion unwield, and explore traps. The first two
will now always work, while the latter is given a 70% fail rate to
approximate how common it is now. (Fun fact: you'd get a message for Ash
preventing teleport traps that would never have triggered in the first
place, giving an inflated sense of how helpful this trap protection was!)

Remove the need to keep data for fully removed mutations

mutation-data.h still contained full blocks of data for many long-removed
mutations (whose functionality was also long-removed, and in most cases
were also completely unobtainable, even on save-upgrade).

This made it possible to sometimes mistake a removed mutation for a real
one, when skimming the file. Moreover, it was still sometimes possible to
obtain a 'removed' mutation if one overlooked setting its weight to 0 when
it was removed.

It is now no longer necessary to keep anything in mutation-data.h for
removed mutations; so long as they are added to removed_mutations[] in
mutations.cc, dummy data will be provided for them automatically.

Mutations for removed species that *can* still be used on save upgrade (and
have some functionality) were left untouched. (I have also removed a few
remaining references to mutations that are now impossible to have.)

Add a graffiti line about name changes.

Use @RANDGEN@ twice to guarantee the two names are different.
Adjust graffiti comments wrt monname.txt names.
Add another graffiti meeting type.
Add another graffiti image option.
Tweak graffiti image naming.

Add meeting-related messages to graffiti.

Including Nemelex, Zin, Xom, and Beogh references.
Add unique-specific complaints to graffiti.
Add another ghost-adjacent graffiti line.
Fix wording of a graffiti line.

Fix a hyper layout bug

This layout code was trying to index a nonexistant usage_grid variable
ever since the code was merged. I've updated it to index what I believe
to be the correct usage grid, which is the one in the main_state
variable.

This bug was uncovered by the lua 5.4 branch with the help of some new
lua stack trace functionality. In general the hyper layout code needs a
serious lookover for errors, as there are still multiple instances of
unused and duplicated functions.

Fix a Lua layout fix

The previous fix indexed the wrong (outer) table when removing eligible
positions. Also use a local reference to the inner table instead of
indexing to get the inner table multiple times per loop iteration.

Fix Lua error in a slightly safer way

The previous commit didn't check for the existence of the key before
trying to remove an entry and it's possible it doesn't exist sometimes.

Additionally cleaned up the line that sets the index as it's no longer
needed; also made the usage_grid not create globally since a reference
to it is always passed around and this just seemed like an omission.

Fix a Lua layout error

This is the same type of error seen in v_pain.lua addressed by 4f17bedc,
but in the "hyper_usage" layout, which uses some very similar code.
Adapt the v_paint.lua fix here as well.
